metadata.title: Highly dispersed metal nanoparticles on TiO2 acted as nano redox reactor and its synergistic catalysis on the hydrogen storage properties of magnesium hydride

journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/he
Highly dispersed metal nanoparticles on TiO2 acted as nano redox reactor and its synergistic catalysis on the hydrogen storage properties of magnesium hydride

sections.heading: Man Chen a, Xuezhang Xiao a,c, Meng Zhang a, Jiaguang Zheng a,
sections.text:
Meijia Liu a, Xuancheng Wang a, Lijun Jiang d, Lixin Chen a,b,*
a State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University,
Hangzhou 310027, PR China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Applications for Batteries of Zhejiang Province, Hangzhou 310013, PR

sections.text:

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Hydrogen storage
MgH2 Co/TiO2 Kinetic analysis
Nano redox reactor
* Corresponding author. State Key Laborato Hangzhou 310027, PR China.
E-mail addresses: xzxiao@zju.edu.cn (X. X https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.04.047 0360-3199/© 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publicati
a b s t r a c t
In this paper, we have synthesized highly dispersed Co metal nanoparticles with the
particle size about 5e10 nm on TiO2 (25e50 nm) for the first time through an extremely facile solvothermal method. It is supposed that the synthesized Co/TiO2 composite can combine the catalytic advantage of both Co and TiO2, exhibiting the superior catalytic effect on the hydrogen de/absorption properties of MgH2. The experimental data confirmed the above supposition and demonstrated that Co/TiO2 additive highly enhances the hydrogen de/absorption kinetics of MgH2 as compared to separate Co or TiO2 additive. Specifically, the MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite begins to desorb hydrogen at about 190 C with a low apparent activation energy of 77 kJ/mol. Besides, the MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite has a desorption peak temperature of 235.2 C, which is 53.2, 94.2 and 132.2 C lower than that of
MgH2eTiO2 (288.4 C), MgH2eCo (329.4 C) and ball-milled MgH2 (367.4 C). Moreover, MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite also exhibits low temperature rehydrogenation properties, which can absorb 6.07, 5.56 and 4.24 wt% H2 within 10 min at the temperature of 165, 130 and 100 C, respectively. It is supposed that such excellent hydrogen desorption properties
and low desorption energy barrier of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite are mainly ascribed to the novel synergistic catalytic effects of Co and TiO2. Herein, we propose a novel catalytic mechanism and think that Co/TiO2 acts as “nano redox reactor”, which can facilitate the
ry of Silicon Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University,
iao), lxchen@zju.edu.cn (L. Chen).
ons LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
dissociation and recombination process of hydrogen, thus reducing the reaction energy
barrier and enhancing the de/rehydrogenation of MgH2.
© 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Magnesium hydride (MgH2) is considered as one of the most promising solid-state hydrogen storage materials, which has
high gravimetric and volumetric hydrogen storage capacity
(about 7.4 wt% and 110 g/L) [1e7]. However, it is still difficult to
achieve the targets set by US DOE [8,9], because of its high
hydrogen desorption temperature (>300 C) and sluggish hydrogen absorption and desorption kinetics [10,11]. There-
fore, a lot of approaches are required to overcome these
problems such as nanosizing, alloying and doping with cata-
lysts [12e24].
Catalytic doping is widely regarded as an effective strategy
[25e30] to improve the hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. Cui et al. had studied the catalytic properties of various tran-
sition metals (TM) [31]. And the results showed that MgeCo
sample has the dehydrogenation peak temperature of 288 C with a low apparent activation energy of 65.4 kJ/mol. Veron
et al. [32] researched the catalytic properties of Co and
MWCNTs. It is stated that the combined cobalt and carbon
nanotube have a better catalytic effect than that of Co and
MWCNTs separately, which can absorbed 6.5 wt% H2 after 100 s and desorbed it in 85 min at 250 C. Wang et al. synthesized a core-shell Co@C catalyst and proposed that the
carbon shell can promote the heat conductivity and sustain
the structure stability, which can enhance the synergetic
catalytic properties of Co@C when doped into MgH2 [33]. In addition, a lot of metal oxides had been verified to be effective
when doped into MgH2. Oelerich et al. [34,35] had studied the effects of various metal oxides (SiO2, Fe3O4, CuO, V2O5, TiO2, Sc2O3 and Mn2O3) on the hydrogen desorption and absorption properties of MgH2. They found that the MgH2/(TiO2)0.01 composite can desorb about 6 wt% H2 at 300 C within 10 min under vacuum. Meanwhile, TiO2 is a multifunction material, which has been widely investigated in the electrochemical
detection techniques [36] and photocatalytic field [37,38]. In
the case of photocatalysis, it is confirmed that the photo-
generated electron-hole pairs in TiO2, which can take part in the oxidation-reduction reaction in the system, making it an
effective photocatalyst [38]. Some researches [39e41] showed
that the introduction of some metals or semiconductors can
improve the photocatalytic properties of TiO2 by hinder the recombination of the electron-hole pairs, which increase the
catalytic performance of TiO2.
Inspired by the above investigations, we expect that the
electron-hole pairs exist in TiO2 under the thermal condition, and the electron-hole pairs (or called charge carriers) may
participate in the dissociation of MgH2 and facilitate its dehydrogenation process. Meanwhile, the introduction of
metal Co can not only weaken MgeH bonding strength, but
also hinder the recombination of the electron-hole pairs. As
far as we known, there is no any investigation reported the
electron-hole pairs mechanism of Co/TiO2 on the improvement of hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. Therefore, we combined the catalytic advantage of both Co and TiO2 and synthesized Co/TiO2 nanocomposite through a facile method in this paper and explored its catalytic effect on the hydrogen
de/absorption properties of MgH2 for the first time. The results demonstrated that Co/TiO2 additive highly enhances the hydrogen de/absorption kinetics of MgH2 as compared to separate Co or TiO2 additive, which can desorb 6.2 wt% hydrogen within 15 min at 250 C and absorb 6.07 wt% H2 within 10 min at 165 C.
It is important to note that this paper provides a simple
method for the synthesis of high-efficiency composite cata-
lysts, and give a novel perspective to understand the catalytic
mechanism towardsmetal/semiconductor composite catalyst
in magnesium hydride. In addition, the superior hydrogen
storage properties of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite make it probable to be applied in the stationary hydrogen storage devices
at medium temperature compared to the single catalyst
catalyzed MgH2 systems [31e33,42e44].

sections.heading: Reagents and synthesis
sections.text:
All chemical reagents in the paper, including Co(NO3)2$6H2O (99%, Aladdin), Ti(OC4H9)4 (98%, Sinopharm), Mg powders (99%, Sinopharm), Co (99.5%, Aladdin), TiO2 (99%, Aladdin) and C6H8O7$H2O (98%, Sinopharm) were used as received.
The Co/TiO2 in the work was synthesized though hydrothermal method and thermal treatment, which are the
common methods to prepare materials [45e48]. Typically,
Co(NO3)2$6H2O (2.9107 g) and C6H8O7$H2O (4.203 g) were dissolved in ethanol (30 ml) with continuous stirring.
Then, Ti(OC4H9)4 (340 ml) was added dropwise and the mixture was stirred for another 1 h. The final solution
was poured into a 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and
heated at 190 C for 12 h. After that, the precipitation was collected and dried at 70 C overnight under vacuum. Finally, the resulting products were heated under Ar at
700 C for 4 h to synthesized Co/TiO2. In addition, MgH2 was synthesized by hydrogenating Mg powders under high
hydrogen pressure (60 bar) at temperature of 380 C for 4 h, which was carried out using the self-made Sievert'stype apparatus. Then, the resulting powders were trans-
ferred to a stainless ball milling tank with a ball to pow-
der ratio of 40:1 (ball milling conditions: 400 rpm; 4 h).
Finally, repeat the above procedures for three times in
order to improve the chemical purity of MgH2.

sections.heading: Synthesis of MgH2-M (M ¼ Co/TiO2, Co and TiO2) composites
sections.text:
The above self-synthesized MgH2 was used as original material and the ball-to-powder weight ratio was 40:1 for all sam-
ples. MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite was obtained by ball milling MgH2 with 10% weight ratio Co/TiO2 nanocomposite for 4 h under the hydrogen back pressure of 10 bar. MgH2eCo, MgH2e TiO2 composites and ball-milled MgH2 were synthesized under the same conditions.

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text:
In order to ensure the composition phases, X-ray diffraction
using X'Pert-PRO diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA was performed. The morphology of the samples
were further characterized using transmission electron mi-
croscope (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20) which is equipped with EDX
detector. And the microscopes were performed at 200 kV. All
the hydrogen storage properties were investigated by home-
made Sievert's-type apparatus. In detail, the temperature programmed dehydrogenation (TPD) profileswere tested from
room temperature to 500 C with the heating rate of 5 K/min. The isothermal dehydrogenation curves were carried out at
210, 220, 250 and 265 C under 0.02 bar hydrogen back pressure to avoid the dehydrogenation before achieving the desired
temperature. The isothermal rehydrogenation curves were
measured at 50, 100, 150 and 200 C under 60 bar hydrogen back pressure. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC,
Netzsch STA 449F3) was performed from 50 to 500 C with the heating rates of 2, 5, 8 and 10 K/min under the flowing argon
(50 ml/min). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, VGES-
CALABMARK II) was performed to analyze the binding energy
(BE) value, which was referenced to the C1s peak at 284.6 eV.

sections.heading: Structure and morphology analysis
sections.text:
The phase components and microstructures were character-
ized by XRD, TEM as well as EDX. Fig. 1(a) shows the XRD
patterns of Co/TiO2 which was synthesized by an extremely facile solvothermal method. Here, the peaks at 2q ¼ 44.2, 51.5, and 75.9 are corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of Co (JCPDS 15e0806). The peaks at 2q ¼ 41.5 and 47.4 belong to Co (JCPDS 89e7373). All the remaining peaks are consistent
with the rutile TiO2 (JCPDS 73e2224). Fig. 1(b) describes the XRD patterns of self-synthesized MgH2 (JCPDS 74e0934) and only a little peaks of MgO can be detected, which may due to
the slight oxidation of MgH2 during the XRD test. Besides, the average crystalline grain sizes of Co, TiO2 and ball-milled MgH2 are 14.3, 17.6 and 11.4 nm, respectively, through the analyses of the Rietveld XRD patterns. Fig. 1(c) shows that
after ball milling the MgH2 and Co/TiO2, only the peaks of MgH2, MgO and Co can be found. Here, the peaks of TiO2 are difficult to distinguish, because the peak positions of TiO2 are close to MgH2. In addition, the XRD profiles of commercial Co, TiO2, MgH2eCo as well as MgH2eTiO2 can be found in the supporting information (Fig. S1).
Fig. 2(a and b) display the microstructures of Co/TiO2. Clearly, Co nanoparticles with the size of 5e10 nm are highly
dispersed on TiO2 (25e50 nm in size). The special structure of Co/TiO2 may enhance its catalytic performance, thus promoting the reversible hydrogen storage properties of MgH2. Fig. 3(a) shows the TEM photograph of ball-milled MgH2eCo/ TiO2 composite, it can be seen that the average size of MgH2 is approximate 200 nm. In addition, the yellow rectangular re-
gion in the dark field image of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite was
of Co/TiO2 nanocomposite.
selected for the EDX mapping analysis. The results are shown
in Fig. 3(b). It is clear that the distribution of Co/TiO2 nanocomposite on MgH2 matrix is relatively uniform, which will much be beneficial to the catalytic properties of Co/TiO2. Besides, the particle sizes of commercial Co and TiO2 are given in the supporting information shown in Fig. S2.
Dehydrogenation properties of MgH2-M (M ¼ Co/TiO2, Co and TiO2) composites
The DSC investigations were performed in order to study the catalytic effects of M (M ¼ Co/TiO2, Co and TiO2). Fig. 4 shows that the ball-milled MgH2 has the dehydrogenation peak temperature at 367.4 C, which is much higher than the M catalyzed MgH2 composites. The dehydrogenation peak temperatures of MgH2-M composites rank in the sequence MgH2e Co/TiO2 (235.2 C), MgH2eTiO2 (288.4 C) and MgH2eCo (329.4 C). Obviously, M can highly enhance the dehydrogenation properties of MgH2. And among them, the assynthesized Co/TiO2 nanocomposite has the best catalytic performance.
From the TPD profiles as shown in Fig. 5, it can be seen that
the MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite begins to desorb hydrogen at 190 C and release about 6.38 wt% hydrogen. In addition, Co
and TiO2 catalyzed MgH2 composites start to desorb hydrogen at about 222 C and 260 C, which are 136 C and 98 C lower than ball-milled MgH2 (358 C). It is notable that MgH2eCo/ TiO2 composite shows a superior catalytic effect among the three catalyzed composites, which may attribute to the syn-
ergistically catalytic effects of Co and TiO2. Therefore, in the following part, more investigations are carried out to study its
hydrogen storage properties. Fig. 6 illustrates the hydrogen
isothermal desorption profiles of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite at different temperatures (265, 250, 220 and 210 C). It can be seen that MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite releases 6.25 wt% hydrogen within 10 min at the temperature of 265 C. As the temperature decreases to 250 C, MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite can release 6.2 wt% hydrogen in 15 min. In addition, the composite also
exhibits good dehydrogenation properties at relatively low
temperature, which can release 5.4 and 4.6 wt% hydrogen
within 100 min at 220 and 210 C, respectively. While, for the ball-milled MgH2, it can hardly desorb hydrogen at 265 C and it can release hydrogen slowly even at 300 C as shown in Fig. S3.
Fig. 7(a) shows the isothermal hydrogen absorption per-
formance of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite. The composite can absorb 6.07, 5.56 and 4.24 wt% hydrogen within 10 min at the
temperature of 165, 130 and 100 C, respectively. Besides, the
MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite can even absorb 4.0 wt% hydrogen at 50 C as the time increases to 10 h (Fig. 7(b)). It is supposed that such outstanding hydrogen absorption properties of
MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite may result from the synergistic catalysis of Co and TiO2. Besides, we compared the de/rehydeogenation properties of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite with other Mg-catalyst system as shown in Table 1. The results
show that MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite has the lowest hydrogen
desorption temperature and superior rehydrogenation
properties.
The cycling performance of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite is further studied as shown in Fig. 8. The hydrogen desorption
and absorption properties are measured at temperature of
265 C (0.02 bar hydrogen back pressure) and 200 C (60 bar hydrogen pressure) respectively. Here, the slight reduction of
dehydrogenation capacity in the second cycle may be caused
by the partially reduced of TiO2, which can be confirmed in the XPS results shown in Fig. S5. Moreover, It is obvious that
MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite can desorb and absorb about 6.0 wt % hydrogen without obviously decline in hydrogen capacity
since the second cycle, which may be the result of efficient
catalysis of highly dispersed Co nanoparticles on the titanium
based matrix.
Apparent activation energy (Ea) was tested to describe the energy barrier for the dehydrogenation of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite. Here, MgH2eCo, MgH2eTiO2 as well as ball-milled MgH2 were also tested for comparison. Fig. S4 shows the DSC curves of the above samples with different heating rates (2, 5,
8 and 10 K/min), and the desorption peak temperatures cor-
responding to each heating rate are used to obtain Ea according to the Kissinger equation shown below:
ln b T2P ¼ Ea=RTP þ C (1)
The Ea of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite is 77 kJ/mol, which is much lower than that of ball-milled MgH2 (161 kJ/mol) as shown in Fig. S5(a). In addition, the individually addition of Co

sections.heading: 2 composite: (a) at 165, 130, 110 and 50 C within 10 min; (b)
60 bar, 200 C).
sections.text:
and TiO2 can also reduce the apparent activation energy of MgH2 (89 kJ/mol for MgH2eTiO2, 129 kJ/mol for MgH2eCo) as shown in Fig. S5(b). Conclusively, Co/TiO2 catalyst can significantly decrease the energy barrier, and play an important role
in promoting the dehydrogenation kinetics of MgH2.
Catalytic mechanism of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite
In order to gain an insight into the reversible de/rehydroge-
nation mechanism of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite. The XRD measurements were carried out to analyze the phase/struc-
ture transformation of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite. Fig. 9(a) and (b) show the dehydrogenation and rehydrogenation states of
the MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite, respectively. It can be seen that all the peaks of MgH2 disappear and transform to Mg during the hydrogen desorption process as shown in Fig. 9(a). Here,
the peaks of Co and TiO2 can still be found. After the rehydrogenation process as shown in Fig. 9(b), we can clearly find
the peaks of MgH2 and MgO. A little peaks of Co can be found when we magnify the selected rectangular region in Fig. 9.
Meanwhile, a little peaks of Mg can be detected in
rehydrogenation state and this may result from the deficient
hydrogenation process of Mg at low temperature. Mentio-
nablely, the peaks of TiO2 are difficult to distinguish in the ball-milling (Fig. 1(c)) and rehydrogenation states ofMgH2eCo/ TiO2 composite, which is because the peak positions of TiO2 are close to that of MgH2.
The TEM measurements are further investigated to
study the microstructures and phase compositions of
MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite. Fig. 10(a and b) show the typical TEM micrographs of MgH2 nanoparticles with an average size about 200 nm. Besides, the red rectangular
region in Fig. 10(b) is selected for SAED and HRTEM ana-
lyses as shown in Fig. 10(c) and (d), respectively. The
electron diffraction rings and lattice fringes of Mg, Co,
TiO2 and MgO can be clearly seen.
Fig. 11(a) and (b) illustrate the microstructures of MgH2e Co/TiO2 composite after rehydrogenation. It can be seen that the Co/TiO2 catalyzed MgH2 composite doesn't aggregate after one cycle of the hydrogen desorption and absorption process.
In addition, from Fig. 11(c) and (d), we can ensure the exis-
tence of MgH2, Co, TiO2 and MgO. The results are exactly in accordance with the XRD data shown in Fig. 9.
Based on the above analyses and experimental data, the
schematic diagram of the probable catalytic mechanism is
shown in Fig. 12, which provides a novel perspective to
explain the synergistic effect of Co and TiO2. According to the previous studies of others, the catalytic properties of TiO2 have been mainly ascribed to the multiple valence titanium
compounds which also been confirmed in our supporting in-
formation shown in Fig. S6. However, in this paper, we sup-
pose a coexisting and prominent catalysis based on the fact
that TiO2 can be irritated not only by photoexcitation [38,39,53,54], but also by thermal excitation [55,56]. The irri-
tated photogenerated holes (charge carriers) in the system
may have the catalytic effects. The number of charge carriers
can be roughly estimated by Boltzmann distribution function
below:
ne ¼ nh ¼ no expð Eg 2kTÞ (2)
Where Eg is the energy gap, ne and nh represent the electron and hole concentrations, respectively. We can get from the
equation that the number of charge carriers increase as the
rise of temperature and the decrease of Eg. Here, in our
ehydrogenation state (a) and rehydrogenation state (b).
experiment, Firstly, the electrons on the valence band of TiO2 are thermally excited to the conduction band. Then, the
electrons on the conduction band will migrate to the surfaces
of Co owing to the higher Femi level of TiO2 than that of Co. As a result, the surfaces of Co are rich in electrons andmore holes
are left on the TiO2. Specifically, during the dehydrogenation process, the metal Co plays two different roles. On one hand,
Co has an almost full D-band electron structure, the unique
electronic structure makes it have higher bond strength with
H (CoeH) than that of MgeH [33], thus facilitating the
destabilization process of MgH2. On the other hand, the surrounding electrons around Co makes it easier for Mg2þ to be
reduced to Mg. At the same time, the H on the interfaces between Mg/MgH2 and Co/TiO2 will get the holes around TiO2, which leads to the formation of H2. During the rehydrogenation process, H2 prefer to dissociate on the surfaces of Co. Meanwhile, the electrons around Co will transfer e to the H atoms and the process below occurs:
H þ e / H (3)
Co/TiO2 composite in the first rehydrogenation state.
Mg þ 2hþ/Mg2þ (4) In terms of Mg, it will get the holes from the TiO2, as a result, Mg2þ is formed. Therefore, Co/TiO2 composite acts as “nano redox reactor”, which can greatly promote the dissoci-
ation and recombination process of hydrogen, thus enhancing
the de/rehydrogenation kinetics of MgH2. Meanwhile, it is notable that more charge carriers are formed as the temper-
ature increases according to the Boltzmann distribution
function above. The increase of charge carriers can enhance
the redox reaction of catalyst, which further accelerate the
hydrogen de/absorption kinetics as the experimental data
shown in Figs. 6 and 7.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The synthesized highly dispersed Co nanoparticles on TiO2 nanocomposite has been introduced into MgH2 for the first time and been confirmed to have a more efficient catalytic
effect than separate Co and TiO2. It is found that the MgH2e Co/TiO2 composite starts to release hydrogen at about 190 C and releases 6.2 wt% hydrogen within 15 min at the temper-
ature of 250 C. In addition, it also absorbs about 4.24 and 1.0 wt% hydrogen in 10min at 100 and 50 C, respectively. The superior hydrogen storage properties of MgH2eCo/TiO2 make it probable to be applied in the stationary hydrogen storage
devices at medium temperature. The enhanced hydrogen
storage kinetics of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite can be attributed to the synergistic effect of Co and TiO2. On one hand, Co has an almost full D-band electron structure, the unique elec-
tronic structure makes it have higher bond strength with H
(CoeH) than that of MgeH, thus facilitating the destabilization
process of MgH2. On the other hand, the electron migrates from the conduction band of TiO2 to metal Co makes Co/TiO2 act like “nano redox reactor”, which can promote the disso-
ciation and recombination process of hydrogen, thus highly
enhancing the hydrogen de/absorption properties of MgH2.

sections.text:

thesized a core-shell Co@C catalyst and proposed that the carbon shell can promote the heat conductivity and sustain the structure stability, which can enhance the synergetic catalytic properties of Co@C when doped into MgH2 [33].

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we have synthesized highly dispersed Co metal nanoparticles with the particle size about 5e10 nm on TiO2 (25e50 nm) for the first time through an extremely facile solvothermal method. It is supposed that the synthesized Co/TiO2 composite can combine the catalytic advantage of both Co and TiO2, exhibiting the superior catalytic effect on the hydrogen de/absorption properties of MgH2. The experimental data confirmed the above supposition and demonstrated that Co/TiO2 additive highly enhances the hydrogen de/absorption kinetics of MgH2 as compared to separate Co or TiO2 additive. Specifically, the MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite begins to desorb hydrogen at about 190 C with a low apparent activation energy of 77 kJ/mol. Besides, the MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite has a desorption peak temperature of 235.2 C, which is 53.2, 94.2 and 132.2 C lower than that of MgH2eTiO2 (288.4 C), MgH2eCo (329.4 C) and ball-milled MgH2 (367.4 C). Moreover, MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite also exhibits low temperature rehydrogenation properties, which can absorb 6.07, 5.56 and 4.24 wt% H2 within 10 min at the temperature of 165, 130 and 100 C, respectively. It is supposed that such excellent hydrogen desorption properties and low desorption energy barrier of MgH2eCo/TiO2 composite are mainly ascribed to the novel synergistic catalytic effects of Co and TiO2. Herein, we propose a novel catalytic mechanism and think that Co/TiO2 acts as “nano redox reactor”, which can facilitate the ry of Silicon Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, iao), lxchen@zju.edu.cn (L. Chen). ons LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
